Description: A pottery mortarium, or shallow grinding-bowl, with a flat base and flaring sides. The fabric in the core is very coarse, apparently common red-brown Nile silt, but the surface is coated with a slip of yellow-green clay. This was probably intended to imitate the appearance of imported mortaria. A hole has been worn through the base by use and the rim is very chipped.
Curator's comments: A. Villing in Villing and Schlotzhauer (eds), Naukratis: Greek Diversity in Egypt, BM Research Publication 162, London 2006, pp.37, 42 and fig. 19.
Bibliographic references: Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.92, fig.8, p.100, p.189, pl.31)
